Why and which SSG

Published on 2023-02-07 by Lemux

Available alternatives

Creating websites is a lot more easy today than it was a few years ago. There a lot of hosting providers ready to fullfill every posible need for a regular website. They are also quite affordable. However I had my eye put on a very particular service: GitHub Pages. This is not a sorprise taking into account that I am a software developer who deals with GitHub from time to time, so it made perfect sense to make use of this great service they opened to the public and so many people are happily using ever since. But, this decision had very specific implications.

GitHub Pages says so

Regular web hosting platfomrs are great but I wanted to try out GitHub Pages for once and that forced me to look at some "serverless" alternatives. Of course that GitHub Pages proposes a really good and solid option named Jekyll, but reading the installation and getting started guides I had the sense that it was way too involved and quirky. Also setting up a whole Ruby stack on my device just to create a dead simple blog was too much for me. There has to be a simpler alternative, right?

The "Jamstack" has been growing rapidly in the last few years and I've been intrigued and curious about it for quite a bit. The speed boost obtained by not depending on a server processing at all is quite interesting but, in my opinion, the killer feature about this web development approach is the free (or almost free) of charge "hosting" availability from CDN networks to S3 buckets. This kind of sites can be deployed virtually anywhere with little to no effort at all.

So many choices

So far so good. However there are currently a lot of options to choose from when we opt for a static site generator (SSG) and they all seem very capable and feature rich since we start reading their "getting starter" guides. The first one I stumbled on was Hugo. This "little" guy grows with new features by day and right now it looks like a swif knive, ranging from small single page sites to batteries-included blogs. From there on I felt overwhelmed and started looking for simpler alternatives for my really basic needs.

maksite.py to the rescue

After searching, reading, trying, messing around and get frustrated with several SSG options I stumbled with maksite.py and it made sense since the very begging. It was tiny. It was simple. It was easy to look into its inner workings to tweak any part of it. It provided the bare bones to be considered a SSG but it was all I actually needed. Indeed it had more than I required for my project and I just forked it and remove the bloat and it was a breeze to do so. That little guy feels like a great tool and I am very happy with it so far.
